conclusion: I'll analyze the thermodynamic process for an ideal gas going from state A to state B to state C, and calculate the total heat transferred.
The process follows path A → B → C as shown in the p-V diagram.
The temperature at state A is 27°C = 300 K (converting to Kelvin).
The axes are pressure (p) in 10⁵ Pa and volume (V) in 10⁻³ m³.
State A: p = 1 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³.
State B: p = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³.
State C: p = 3 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 2 × 10⁻³ m³.

premise: State A: p = 1 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³; State B: p = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³.
conclusion: Process A → B: Constant volume (isochoric/isometric) process.

premise: State B: p = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 6 × 10⁻³ m³; State C: p = 3 × 10⁵ Pa, V = 2 × 10⁻³ m³.
conclusion: Process B → C: Diagonal line, which is neither constant pressure nor constant volume.

premise: Process B → C: Diagonal line in the p-V diagram.
pV = nRT; State A: p_A·V_A = nR·T_A.
pV = nRT; State B: p_B·V_B = nR·T_B.
